title: Narrative in 2018

embed.description: There's a little misconception floating around the internet, that when it comes to Riot and League of Legends, there is a single "lore team" who write all the stories, decide all the character backgrounds, and is solely responsible for building out Runeterra. The truth is, the history of our lore is a lot more disjointed than that.

body: Key notes are Ionia, Bilgewater, Darkin and Void lore in 2018

Hi Scathlocke,

I really want to discuss the Varus update. I both liked it and disliked it.

I think part of the reason that some people received it so poorly is that his conviction / motivation was not shown as strongly in the new lore as the old one. In the old one he accepted evil power (that he fully and rationally knew was evil) into himself, in the new lore he did it because, "screw the prophecy" which just doesn't carry as much weight as _knowing_ would. The sacrifice he made by giving himself to the power would have been way more impressive if he knew he was giving himself over to evil.

I would have been 100% happy with the update if he had taken up the power or accepted it already knowing how evil the power was, but instead I'm left feeling a little bit disappointed. It wouldn't even have required much change to the new story in order to preserve this.

**Is there any chance you folks at Riot could do more to avoid doing this kind of unnecessary removal of motives/conviction with characters in the future? It would be nice if the team did more to try to understand what it is that people relate to in characters so that doesn't get lost in character updates.**

If you have ever seen the anime Boku No Hero, picture the character Stain. He's undeniably in the wrong, but he's cool because he had the conviction to do what many others would not be willing to do if they were in his shoes.

Thanks for reaching out :-)

I agree with you on many points, and we absolutely will try to avoid this sort of thing, going forward. In the case of Varus, the story content and video was all already decided before I started at Riot, but I was interested to see how it was received.

I'd much rather spend time foreshadowing changes in a way that feels organic and true to existing characters, than completely overhauling in one blast.

And I hope you'll hold us to our word on that, and keep checking in to let us know how you think we're doing. :-)

Well it seems like ultimately (I don't know if Riot stated as such, but it feels that way), if there's new lore that Riot finds more compelling than the old lore, then they'll go for the new one, knowing that fans of the old lore will feel jilted. It's been that way for a few vgus, and even regular lore updates. It's hard to hold Riot to their word, when it seems like they just do whatever.

As I said, hopefully we'll start to build your trust on things like this.

Old lore is not necessarily good lore, any more than new lore would be automatically better. I'd always prefer to *develop* the setting, rather than overhaul and retcon bits of it.

The Varus incident tbh was just horrid especially due to the fact that Varus's lore was good lore and didn't hold the dark and secret past problem like most of the old and current lore. He now has the problem of the dank and secret past while also possessing the pantheon problem where he isn't even the same person now. Honestly that event by itself makes me doubt future lore. There was so much misinformation to the point where it wasn't funny. Honestly does the narrative team actually consider that a success because there were rioters claiming that it was a month ago? Also how do you actually plan to not surprise us with the lore updates because they all sort of just pop up randomly with maybe a notice a month beforehand.

I think it's been said already, but Narrative was not brought in on Varus until quite a long time after the video's lore direction had been created. Certainly all of that content was decided before I started working here, so I can't really speak about it with any authority.

Honestly, though - no, I personally don't believe that was a successful delivery of new content. Regardless of whether or not the actual ideas resonated with a majority or minority of players, the messaging of the update felt inconsistent, and it has left a sense of dissonance between the lore and the in-game champion. I will see what we can do about that dissonance, going forward.

I will also speak to DyQuil and find out what he meant about the communication though - I don't think anyone on Narrative has anything to offer, retrospectively, about the Varus update.

Varus is going to need a completely new VO, at the very least.  I also hope you guys can avoid the whole cheesy "Varus easily kills everyone in his path until something cute or important to the intellectual property is in the way and his Heartsworn interferes" scenario the color text laid out.

I would also ask that Wenceslaus not be involved in another champ rewrite after lying about the impact of the Varus changes, but that's just me.  I don't like/trust people who lie, which is why I don't believe him when he says the changes weren't politically motivated.  Unfortunately, one bad apple...
 
> I will also speak to DyQuil and find out what he meant about the communication though - I don't think anyone on Narrative has anything to offer, retrospectively, about the Varus update.

In December, DyQuill promised a direct response from the Varus team to the negative feedback.  This quickly became a "holistic approach" essay because, I assume, no one on the team wanted to directly address those concerns or issues.  Even then, the only questions actually addressed were the softball ones.  Questions like "Why did the team lie when the story was leaked on the PBE?," among others, were ignored as "loaded."  (Whatever that means.)

This was in early January.  Since then, nothing from DyQuill other than some softball nonsense when the Annie video dropped.

I have no idea if DyQuill even writes for Narrative or some other department like Marketing.

It just seems to me that two months to write a "this is how we approach our champions" essay is a bit much given how important it seemed in December.

Hey, I’m gonna post my question here too in case this is a more convenient place for this discussion. I’m super thrilled to see this article, ESPECIALLY with the promise (threat?) of new Void lore, but I am curious about one thing:

I’m surprised to hear you guys are revisiting Bilgewater again, considering I’d argue Bilgewater (especially MF) has gotten far and away the most lore since the Great Revamp, what with the 5 bios and color stories, the two short stories, the comic, the cinematic, and the website. What made you guys decide to tackle them again as opposed to something like the Freljord or Bandle City?

It's on our wishlist of things we'd like to tackle in 2018. There is some inconsistency in the way certain bits of lore have been presented - if we got to revisit Bilgewater, I'd want to make sure we were adding to the lore and clarifying it, to make it more enjoyable for players. :-)

Freljord and Bandle City aren't _off_ the table, though...

I’m curious what about the Bilgewater lore you think was lacking in player enjoyment. Since usually the Bilgewater event tops the list in best lore events Riot has done thus far. 

And while I can only speak for myself, Miss Fortune is in my opinion your best character. Relatable themes, intelligent planning, a touch of badass, and a story that hasn’t devolved into another boring ancient evil.
